At the start, the players set out their pieces on the five squares immediately in front of their own Castle, remembering which piece is the Spy. During his turn a player may move any one of his pieces in any direction as many squares as he wishes. A piece is not allowed to jump over nor occupy the same square as another piece. Instead of moving, a player may choose to interrogate an enemy piece. This is done by moving one of his pieces to rest orthogonally adjacent to the piece to be questioned, and on the next turn asking if it is the Spy. The other player must identify the piece so questioned. If it is the Spy, then the questioner has won the game; however if it is not, then the asking player loses his piece, and if the asking piece was the Spy, then he also loses the game. The rules do not state that it is illegal to occupy one’s own Castle, but one must assume that it is, in order to avoid stalemate. Also the rules do not make it clear as to what happens when a player has all his pieces blocked and cannot move on his turn.

Bluffing is an important part of the game. It is not mandatory to interrogate a piece, even having moved into position to do so, neither is it obligatory to remain in position to be questioned. One can thus chase an opposing piece around the board only to discover eventually that it was a decoy, and in the meantime the enemy Spy is well positioned to enter one’s own stronghold.

As it is only permissible to enter a Castle orthogonally, it is possible to set up an impregnable defence, by placing a piece on the squares either side of it. This ploy however, will limit the number of pieces that one can move, and unless one employs the Spy as a defender, increases the chances of one’s Spy being exposed.

name: Turf War
description:
Turf War is a strategic tile game for 2-4 players. Roll dice and spend dollars in order to move your pieces around the city. Control special tiles and play cards in order to give you more pieces, money, moves and some other special advantages.

Win the game by controlling your own turf effectively, controlling the city centre, and by eliminating rival bosses.

Two expansion decks and optional advanced rulesets add to the complexity of the game.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Modular Board, Tile Placement
publishers: The Game Crafter, LLC, Too Much Games

name: Elemental Clash: Tribes
description:
Turmoil has befallen the lands and the tribes are at war. Choose your which side you are on: Will you fight with the earthbound Troll tribes, who are determined to hold their wooded, mountainous homelands in the north against their foes? Will you establish dominion over the skies at the side of the ethereal Spirits? Do you share the fanatical rage of the Goblins keen on expanding their territories or will you help the solemn and elusive Merfolk protect their watery domains?
While war wages, mighty Spellcasters emerge from the depths of space and time, summoning mighty Creatures and casting powerful Spells to battle each other...

The aim of the game is to reduce the cards in your opponent’s card-deck (or Spellbook) to zero by using the Spells and Creatures in your Spellbook. Players take turns that always follow the same structure. For each point of damage a Player receives through Creatures or Spells, he or she puts the top card of his or her deck on his or her Discard Pile (or Archive). Is a player unable to draw a card, he or she loses immediately.

The third expansion of Elemental Clash is all about Creatures (it features more Creature and less Spell cards than previous sets), in particular the four major tribes, each being associated with one of the four elements: Trolls (Earth), Spirits (Air), Goblins (Fire) and Merfolk (Water). Furthermore, Elemental Clash:

In a "Mini-Expansion" included in the game, Tribes offers an exciting new variant of play, with Spellcaster cards being introduced. Players can choose one out of the ten different Spellcasters included and build a deck around him or her. Each Spellcaster has a pre-set deck size, hand size and number of cards which you draw each turn as well as a permanent "Static Ability" and a "Flip Ability" which gives you a certain benefit once, but shuts down the "Static Ability".

Featuring artwork of Enggar Adirasa and Andreas Propst.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy
mechanics: Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Awesome Possum
description: Awesome Possum is a press your luck game where players are possums trying to cross the highway to save their possum babies. Each turn players decide whether to attempt a crossing or go home with the babies they've already rescued. If they decide to cross the road, they choose which section of the road they want to cross. After all players have chosen a section of road, those sections are revealed to see if they were successful. Successful crossings allow them to rescue more possum babies. Unsuccessful crossings send the possum back home until next round. Play continues until all possum babies have been rescued or all possums have gone home. The winner is the possum with the highest score, 2pts for each of their own baby possums and 1pt for each of an opponent's baby possums.

name: Racial Wars: Or'grakrun
description:
Racial Wars is the first Polish fantasy card game, designed by Åukasz Kozak. Currently, the game is designed for 2-4 players. However, in the second edition the rules and game sets for 1 player will be presented.

The War of Races takes place in Ithilion world and 12 different races and 1 neutral race take part in it. The goal is to conquer the opponent’s residence or to eliminate his leader from the battlefield. The game also becomes more strategic as you play on two fronts.

Racial Wars in not a collectible card game but thanks to random additions, the player can make his own, exclusive card deck. Each card has its own unique abilities and unrepeatable pictures.

Players start with only leader in front of them and build plateau of cards in front of them - some cards generate resources - different for different races - which are then used to put more powerful creatures into the table. Then, each turn the battle takes place - player who is currently attacking chooses units to attack and defending blocks their attacks with his own to protect his leader. The purpose of the game is to kill enemy leader.

The game is based on a fantasy world of Ithilion, which arose in author’s and his coworkers’ minds. If you want to know the new world and characters living in it, or make a new era in Ithilion world and fight at one of the races’ side, join the Racial Wars community and create with us new days of Ithilion world.

Leader’s set "Or'grakrun" is a set which includes the deck of Dragons based on the black leader of dragons Or'grakrun.

Dragons are a race of wild beasts inhabiting high mountains of the Ithilion world. As Elerter-the Angel Creator kept his seed long in his wings, dragons have become almost immortal. Nobody really knows how long these great beasts live because their bodies show no signs of old age or fatigue. Their skin is hard like a stone, eyes will see even the remotest areas and the fire that comes out of their mouths is difficult to extinguish.

name: Patrick Moore's Astronomy Game
description:
Explore the solar system and outer space, visiting celestial objects and obtain information and points. The game starts and finishes at Earth and the winner is the one who gains the most points, not necessarily the first one back home.

On your turn roll and move along the track, through the solar system and into outer space and back, visiting as many celestial bodies as you can. The first two players back get extra points, so don't take too long. Use your fuel wisely to maximise your points, and dock with other players to gain extra speed.

name: Masters' Series: Adventure 1 â The Deadly Hand of Zargon (fan expansion for HeroQuest)
description:
The biggest challange to making these games has always been, How to keep it fresh and new. After making the 8th game in the adventure series, My Heroes wanted very much to keep the mercanaries. The quests got to big for the original board. So we created a bigger board. My first Son wanted more fighting, my second Son wanted more treasure, and I wanted more furniture. Add to this all the monsters, cards, tiles and rules from all the expansions and we created the Masters' Series. This is a very exciting adventure that we're sure your going to love. It will require a bit of work on your part to create the board and tiles. You will need to buy quite a few extra monsters and furniture for the game. But all of this is provided for you in the making a Masters' Series game booklet.
The pages for this adventure are available to download at "Dragonkingdoms.co.uk" and yahoo's group site "HeroQuest- hero quest" for free. You do need to join the group to access the file's section where they are stored. The photo section of this site will allow you to read the story and look at the maps to see if this game is something you would like to play. Your adventure awaits!
categories: Adventure, Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Fantasy, Miniatures

name: Third Person Shooter
description:
Third Person Shooter (or TPS for the acronym-hungry) is basically a tactical First Person Shooter transmogrified into a tabletop game. The intent was to have as few rules as possible, to avoid them getting in the way of the fragfest. TPS can be taught in under 5 minutes, and a game round usually takes less than 25 minutes. TPS scales well, and runs with little or no lag with 8 to 10 players!

TPS uses simultaneous movement and combat with a minimum of fuss and constraints, such as hexes or movement allowances. As such TPS has been accused of thinking far outside the conventional box for tabletop games.

TPS pits the Terrorists against the counterterrorists in the classic struggle for most frags and points to buy cool upgrades and fancy equipment. Supported game modes in v.1.0 are Hostage-rescue and Bomb placement/disarmament.

More features will come with future patches and major versions.

The future of TPS is currently uncertain - But in a good way - We are looking into doing a redesign and getting it published :)

name: A Modest Inclination toward Speed
description:
The road ahead beckons, and you want to run the course from start to finish as quickly as possible before you run out of gas. But looking ahead, some of those curves are a little steep. Perhaps it is best not to drive too fast.

Each turn you play one card from your hand, adjust your speed accordingly, and move over the appropriate number of road sections. Taking a curve too fast or a jump too slow results in damage which is paid by discarding player cards. If you cross the finish line card, you win. If you run out of cards or are unable to take enough damage, you lose.

Created for the 2012 Solitaire Print and Play Contest

name: Robbin' Eggs
description: The robin has placed positive and negative numbers on the bottom of the 18 eggs in his nest. On your turn, turn over a card and follow the sometimes silly instructions. Usually this means roll the 24-sided die and then turn over eggs as instructed to try to try to get the sum of the eggs as close to the number rolled as possible. The difference between the sum of the eggs turned over and the roll of the die results in penalty points. And you might get to rob eggs from an opponent who is doing well or scramble the eggs to make it hard for the your opponents to remember where certain numbers are. It's a game of math, memory, and luck!

name: Military Modelling Guide to Solo Wargaming
description:
The book contains a variety of information and ideas for solo wargaming from small scale skirmishes to large campaigns. Each scenario contains basic rules so that they are playable straight away without reference to another ruleset. However, the book also provides ideas that can be applied to whichever ruleset the reader prefers.

From the back cover:

"Solo wargaming is growing rapidly in popularity. In this book, Stuart Asquith, editor of Practical Wargamer magazine sets out the reasons for solo play and its attractions and advantages.

The book covers all manners of actions from small-scale skirmishes through to campaigns, and the historical spread of the contents is extensive. Other aspects of solo wargaming discussed include chance cards, terrain, the unpredictable enemy, maps and map making, supplies, the weather and postal play.

Illustrated with photographs and line drawings, Military Modelling Guide to Solo Wargaming is the definitive book on the subject."

name: FORTALEZA
description:
These are difficult times: the war is imminent in ungoverned lands.Around the remains of an ancient Celtic settlement, a group of thugs, hastily, built a fortress to protect themselves from the enemies who pursued them and to begin a new life.
You will need to collaborate in the construction of the fortress. Your effort will be rewarded with the leadership of the square if your men and women working hard against those thugs.

The player in turn makes one or two actions possible, using two cards from your hand.Then fill your hand with two new cards from the deck and ends their turn.

Actions:
-Obtain resources
-Develop tiles
-Build a Wall
-Build a Door
-Build a Tower
-Build a Guild
-Place fundraiser
-Retreat to the temple

Winner of the 1st contest of "Ojo al dado" (Eye to die) of creation of boardgames ( 23th february 2013)link

name: Mia and me: Mia und ihre Freunde
description:
A children's game set in the universe of the 2011 live action/CGI animated television series "Mia and me".

The game contains 36 cards with 4 symbols from the world of Centopia on each card. The cards are placed face up on the table. The same symbols are also printed on three dice. For each possible die roll combination there are exactly three correct cards. As soon as the active player has rolled the dice, all players simultaneously search for the corresponding cards. When a player has found such a card, he/she marks it with their player chit. When all three cards have been marked, players who have marked a correct card get to keep that card. Player chits on incorrect cards get removed from the game for the next round. The first player to collect 8 or more cards wins the game.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: MafiaDollar promo card pack
description:
A pack of promotional cards for MafiaDollar i.e. a five card mini expansion: an item, a warehouse card, an event and two loot cards.

The only new rule concernes the loot cards. These cards are only scored if one player has both.

name: Chequered Flag: Classic Formula Racing
description:
Classic Formula Racing is a semi-statistical solitaire replay game on the world of F1. It appears in several sets, each one playable by itself.
The first set contains data for replaying F1 seasons 1950-1952, plus non championship races from 1946 to 1952.
the system uses d6 and d10 and a few tables to recreate each single race. basically, each driver is rated for qualifying, race, retirement percentage; in the advanced game, there are rating for quickness, Stamina and Finish, plus rules for collisions, fastest lap, weather and so on.

name: The Lord of the Rings Strategy Battle Game: The Free Peoples
description:
Middle-earth is home to many races, most of them much older than the men that now dominate it. Amongst them are the Elves and the Dwarves, who have fought against Sauron and his armies for centuries. Though their experience in war is legendary, these races are now few in number, their time in Middle-earth close to an end. As such, their armies are often small, but comprised of powerful elite warriors, all of them ready to fight for the fate of Middle-earth.

This 64-page Sourcebook for The Lord of the Rings contains all the rules you'll need to field an army from The Free Peoples (including army lists for Elves, Dwarves, Hobbits, Ents, The Fellowship and the White Council), as well as detailed background information and scenarios.

You must possess a copy of The Lord of the Rings Strategy Battle Game in order to use the contents of this book.
categories: Book, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Wargame
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Death in the Dark Continent: Supplement 1
description:
The supplement is in electronic format only and puts together in an organic way a lot of updates published for the game. In the supplement many optional rules are found too as are errata and emendaments to the rules.

From the back cover:
"This PDF downloadable supplement brings together a handful of amendments to the Death In The Dark Continent rules with some optional rules for stratagems and psychological warfare, and the full set of rewritten army lists. They have now been brought together into one definitive collection."

NOTE: As per my conversation with the creator, this PDF is no longer available for download because the information in it is included in the newest printing of the rule book.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Krimi Total Fall 9: Drei Rosen fÃ¼r Charlie
description:
"Krimi Total" is a series of murder mystery games in which players act out their role and try to solve the mystery.

In Drei Rosen für Charlie (Three Roses for Charlie), Lady von Bull wants to celebrate the recent award for a new rose grown in her rose garden. The party is disrupted by the death of her french bulldog Charlie.

5-6 players (2 male, 3 female; 1 m/f) take on the roles of Lady von Bull, her son, his fiancée, the horticulturist, the housekeeper and (optionally) the inspector. Together they try to figure out what happened on that evening, and how and why Charlie died.

name: La Hache & le Feu: TorkreyghÃ¨n de Kisadyn
description:
This expansion add a new hero to the game. Torkreyghèn is a fighter but he can use magic. He is specialized with attacks and armor using.

With this expansion comes the rules for blocking attacks with a shield.

Components:
1 cardboard figurine
1 Hero sheet
1 Hero marker
8 equipment cards
8 magical objects cards
11 potion cards
many pawns
categories: Adventure, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Role Playing, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers

name: La Hache & le Feu: Demnukys l'ExÃ©cutrice
description:
This expansion add a new hero to the game. Demnukys is an assasin woman. She uses magic as well as fighting abilities. She is specialized with ranged attacks.

With this expansion comes the rules for blocking attacks with a shield.

Components:
1 cardboard figurine
1 Hero sheet
1 Hero marker
8 equipment cards
8 magical objects cards
11 potion cards
many pawns
categories: Adventure, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Role Playing, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers

name: The Deep
description:
A group of friends enters a cave, which is something more than what it really seems. The cave has some supernatural abilities. Legends and tales say that the cave could fulfill a person's ambitions, but there would always be a price. Our group of friends however doesn't know the exact nature of this place and they start being overwhelmed by hallucinations and weird experiences. When they will finally fathom what this situation is all about -themselves- it will be too late. Some of them have already started to lose their sanity...

The Deep', is a game in which players try gain experience cards through bidding and try to surpass challenges and events of a deck of cards called The Road. Some challenges might make the game co-operative for just a second, but don't be fooled! In a place like The Deep it's every man for himself.

A second deck with Events and Conditions called The Book, makes the game more interesting, as players may draw cards from The Book by paying sanity. The Book cards may help you win the game, but a couple of experiences must also be earned, or else The Book might not be as useful as hoped.

Each game turn is divided in 4 phases:

The Road: Road cards are revealed.
The Experience: Experience cards are revealed and auctioned.
The Silence: Players play experience cards.
The Book: Players may pay sanity to draw Book cards.


The game ends if a player has fulfilled 3 experiences, or if a player has no sanity left. The ambitions of each player are then revealed and the player with the most points is the winner. In case of a tie, the player among the tied that has the most sanity left is the winner.

After all, a madman cannot always win...

name: Malifaux: Guild Austringer
description:
From the Malifaux Tactica Wiki:

He's a guy with a bird. How scary can that be? The answer, apparently, is "very scary." With a very long range and the ability to ignore Line of Sight, the Austringer has quickly become a premier Guild Minion.

The Austringer has an average 4" Walk, cannot Charge and beyond Quick Retreat (see below), has no other way of enhancing his own mobility. Fortunately, after the Austringer finds a nice piece of terrain to hide in, his long reach means he'll rarely needs to move anyway.

The Austringer is armed with a Raptor - a Range 12 weapon that ignores cover modifiers and Line of Sight. This means you can sit behind a huge piece of blocking terrain and still attack up to 12" away, ignoring any negative flips from cover that your opponent is trying to use to avoid getting hit.

The Austringer has little direct synergy with any one Master. The closest is Lucius (a Henchman), but in any case, he still makes for a good choice in your average Guild crew, regardless of who's leading.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Horror, Miniatures

name: Dust Tactics: Joe vs Sigrid
description:
Bazooka Joe and Sigrid were the two heroes in the original (now out of print) Dust Tactics Core Set. For a limited time, Dust-models.com offered a pre-painted pack of just these heroes in two different paint schemes.

If you already own the original (now out of print) Dust Tactics Core Set, these would be considered an "upgrade" or an "accessory" because they are simply pre-painted versions of what you have.

If you only own the Dust Tactics Revised Core Set, these would be considered an expansion because they add two new playable heroes to the game.
categories: Miniatures, Science Fiction, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Senet Cardgame
description:
The cardgame is an extension of the game of Senet. It is played with the Senetboard and the pawns, but you play with the cards instead of the dicesticks.
The basic rules of Senet remain valid. You have 5 cards in your hand, so you have the choice wich move you will make.
There are a few cards with a surprise: you can force the opponent to jump into the Nile, you can take his cards and change them with yours, you can jump to the protected fields, ...
There is another kind of interaction than with the dicesticks and you can control the game and develop more strategy.
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game

name: HEX-A-GONE
description:
HEX-A-GONE is an abstract strategy game played on an hex-hex tile board. Players move their pawns on tiles worth 1,2 or 3 points. They collect the starting tiles of their pawns, thus shrinking the board with every move. The goal is to have the most points when no player has legal moves or everybody passed.

HEX-A-GONE appears to be very similar to Hey, That's My Fish! but with a couple of extra special tiles: the "portal" and the "patch".
mechanics: Modular Board, Point to Point Movement

name: Wizard's Brew: Dark Summoner Expansion
description:
The Spell cards are at the heart of the game Wizard’s Brew. Each of these special expansion sets of Spell Cards generates the Element cards shown on the Spell cards. This phase takes only a few seconds while you select these powerful Element cards.

You then use these Element cards to bid on and collect Ingredients. The race to collect Ingredients is the goal of the game! To increase the strategy and
interactivity between the players, there are Spell cards that let you bid extra cards or different cards. There are also Spell cards that let you change the rules of the bidding. So you need to maneuver to get the right Spells at the right time and to be in the right Area of the board to take advantage of the Spells you control.

The Dark Summoner expansion is really an interesting assortment of extra Spell cards. The Force of Nature card might be the most powerful one in the game— it certainly adds greatly to your ability to collect Element Cards faster than your opponents. The two Red Spell cards are 2 of only 3 that are available for this game. Soul Drain and Plunderer are meant to increase the interactivity between players!

name: HeroClix: Pacific Rim Mini-Game
description:
The world is under attack! Can you pilot your Jaeger units to victory against the Kaiju? Recreate the epic battle scenes from the movie, or create your own!

Recreate all of the fantastic action from the Pacific Rim feature film with the Pacific Rim HeroClix Mini-Game, featuring two HeroClix figures, an exclusive fold-out game board, a quick-start rules sheet, a scenario sheet, 32 Horde Tokens, and dice.

Includes:

2 Collectible Miniature game pieces
2 Character cards
1 Full-color game board
32 Tokens
2 Dice
categories: Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: H.G. Wells' Little Orc Wars
description:
From the Quick-Play Rules:

"H.G. Wells' Little Orc Wars is a miniatures game based on the rules and concepts published by the genius science fiction author nearly a century ago. It is, in fact, one of the most flexible, innovative, and fast-paced miniatures rule systems for use with fantasy miniatures and models ever created. Indeed, a primary feature of this game is that it can be played with virtually any miniatures, setting it apart from the vast majority of fantasy miniatures games, which demand that only their branded products be used to play.

* * *

Other highlights of the complete book include advanced melee rules that expand upon the basic ones created by Wells that are presented here: guidlines on building props and models; examples of play depicting some of the best wargaming models currently available, including those by the Miniature Building Authority, Armocast, Fantascene, Dwarven Forge, and Flying Tricycle and action-oriented images of miniatures in play."

Little Orc Wars and its predecessor, Little Wars from H.G. Wells, provide a simple set of rules for wargaming using miniatures (or anything else you can find to represent troops). Little Orc Wars focuses on fantasy and the basic rules for moving troops, melee, ranged combat, terrain effects, etc.--although modern rules are more complex, these rules capture the feel of combat with very little effort or time.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Book, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Spell Chess: an Expansion to Chess
description:
Enter the world of Spell Chess! A deck of spell cards to use while playing a normal game of Chess.

Spell Chess is an exciting addition to your Chess playing experience. It consists of a deck of cards that modify and change the normal rules of chess as you play. It creates exciting new challenges to the existing game, as well as opens up new emergent strategies and tactics.

Spell Chess is a two player game consisting of your chess set and the Spell Chess expansion. The pieces are still the same but, by drawing cards from the spell deck you will change the game with an ever twisting chain of spells.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Variable Player Powers

name: Topfrosch
description:
Topfrosch consists of a wooden frame, four frogs (made from coconut halves), a sand timer, and 160 marbles in four colors. Marbles represent the insects that the frogs want to catch.

Set the frame on the table, place the marbles inside, then flip the sand timer. Each player grabs his frog and pushes it through the arena, trying to get as many marbles as possible under the frog before the 30-second timer runs out.
Topfrosch includes various scoring versions: In the kids' version, each marble counts one point. For adults, each color counts only for one player/team, while other colors are deducted. In some versions, one color counts for everyone, etc. Whoever has the most points after a round wins.

name: Koi Pond: Four Walls
description:
Protect your koi pond from those pesky turtles, cranes and housecats! This one-card mini-expansion for KOI POND grants you immunity from some of these nasty pests. Watch out, because your opponents have their own immunity, too! Add this card to your existing Koi Pond game for fun new strategies!

How to add this to Koi Pond:
While setting up the game, place this card in the middle of the play area. Orient it so that each suit icon faces one player. (In a 2-player or a 3-player game, some suits will go onclaimed.)

The following rule will be in effect during the whole game.

Your opponents cannot use turtles, cranes or housecats to score points from your koi of the suit facinc you.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Night of the Saucers
description:
The year is 1984. Your city is under siege. Grey alien soldiers are everywhere. Alien rule is immanent. It's up to you and the teenage trouble making Task Force to save humanity. The Night of the Saucers is upon us, and Earth's only hope just got out of detention.

Night of the Saucers is a collaborative game for 1 to 4 players, ages 8 and up. The average game lasts about an hour, but its not uncommon for a game to stretch towards the two hour mark. It all depends on how many missions you choose to complete and how many cards you decide to include in the alien deck.

Each player controls 3 high school students that are stuck in detention when aliens attacked and take over the city. Now it's up to the students to take the city back. You must move about the board searching buildings for supplies to fight the aliens with. At the end of every turn, each player draws an alien card that deploys new aliens onto the board and directs the movements of the alien army. Sometimes devastating Saucer Strikes will be drawn that blow up the buildings tiles and everything on them. This makes the board treacherous to navigate and supplies harder to come by. The way you win is by completing Task Force missions or by surviving the alien deck.

Night of the Saucers is a fun and easy game with cool miniatures set in an 80s action-movie inspired environment. We like to say it's like Red Dawn meets Independence Day with the Breakfast Club. Are you listening Hollywood?
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Player Elimination, Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Monuments: Wonders of Antiquity â Vergil: Writers of Antiquity
description:
Vergil: Writers of Antiquity consists of three additional cards for the board game Monuments: Wonders of Antiquity. Now when Vergil, Homer or Ovid mention your monuments in their epics, you'll become more and more famous.

By paying a certain amount of monument cards, you can attract a writer's attention, making one of your monuments more famous than the same monument owned by an opponent or making your historians work more effectively. When you take the "earn victory points" action, the writer's "money bag" joker symbols count as a helmet, ship or scroll,
earning you addition victory points.

Vergil: Writers of Antiquity, the fifth expansion for Monuments, is a limited edition item from OSTIA Spiele.
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game

name: Galaxy Dice
description:
From the Box:
In this "push your luck" dice game, players attempt to acquire stages by matching their dice rolls to the icons on the card. These cards make you more powerful against the bosses. Each boss that falls before you unlocks a more powerful die. Once a player has defeated a set number of bosses, the game is over and the person with the highest core is the winner.

Featuring all pixel artwork, 5 unique scrolling stages, 20 enemies, 5 bosses, and even Basic and Advanced variants.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Solo / Solitaire Game, Team-Based Game

name: Rockwell:  Explosion Cards
description:
Set of 8 cards that was a Kickstarter stretch goal and a giveaway at Spiel 2013.

Description from the Kickstarter-page: "During extraction, this card triggers an explosion that makes a driller lose a power level. For players looking for danger and additional challenges!"
categories: Economic, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Industry / Manufacturing, Number
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Modular Board, Worker Placement

name: Hemlock
description: Hemlock is 2-5 player card game the goal of which is to poison the Royalty of your opponent(s). In each round, the ‘Conspirator’ leads a card from her hand face-down in the center of the play area. Moving clockwise, players place cards for their value or their ability to control or manipulate the trick while at the same time trying to determine whether they want the face-down Lead card to go to their team or an opponent. The winner of the trick assigns the face-down card to either the ‘Target’, herself, or, if the winner of the trick is the Target then to any player she chooses. Once a certain number of cards have been assigned the game ends, and the face-down cards assigned to each player are resolved. The winner is the player or team with the most Royalty Points at the end of the game.

name: Panique dans la Ruche
description:
"Our bees are in danger!
In the meadow insecticides dominate. Pollution becomes unbearable.
The climate change disrupts the environment and now the Asian hornet scourge!"

In each round, you can raise or move a bee on the board. You explore the bushes to find the precious pollen. But be careful not to fall into the traps.

The game can be played with or without fighting.

You win the game by beeing the first to collect and place 3 pollen into the bottom of the beehive. The other way to win is to be the first to elimitate the most opponent bees.
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Pick-up and Deliver

name: Deep, Dark, Random Forest
description: DDR Forest is a two-player constructible board game that combines strategy and luck. Collect three Relic Cards and land on your opponent’s Starting Square. Die rolls determine your movement. Cards are played to hinder your opponent’s progress. The board unfolds at random each turn allowing for a different map every game.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Modular Board, Take That

name: No Room at the Zoo
description:
It's not easy trying to get all your animals into the zoo because there just isn't enough room for all of them. You may even end up with more animals than you started with.

The zoo is divided into four coloured zones. In each zone there are coloured rings for individual animals. Game play chooses the coloured zone each player must place an animal in and as an animal cannot be placed on a ring which is overlapped by a ring already containing an animal things can get a little squashed. Any player that cannot place an animal in the required zone must pick up all the animals in that zone. The winner is the first to get rid of all his animals.

name: Space Station
description:
On a magnetic game board, players in Space Station take turns building cities, stations and spaceships; invading the stations owned by opponents, and expanding their cities and stations.

To set up, players place a predetermined number of their pieces on the game board, based on the number of players; pieces come in three sizes: cities (large), stations (medium) and spaceships (small). On a turn, you take one of the following actions:


Build a city, station or spaceship — Take one of these tokens from your reserve and place it next to a friendly token of the same size or larger already on the board.



Invade an opponent's city or station — If one of your pieces touches an opponent's, you can place one of your smaller tokens on top of it.



Establish a spaceship base — If you have a token on top of an opponent's city or station, you can place one of your spaceships next to this invaded piece.



Expand to a city or station — If you have two spaceships or a spaceship and station close to one another, you can place one of your stations or cities so that it touches both of these pieces. You can expand with pieces that have invaded opponents, and if you're set up right, you can both expand and invade at the same time!


Players keep placing pieces until everyone has passed in turn because no space remains on the game board. Players score two points for each uninvaded station of their color on the game board, then lose one point for each station not placed. Whoever has the highest score wins!

name: Noms
description:
Noms is a four-player Whist-like card game with bidding, in which the bidder's partner is chosen by calling a card, and the identity of the partner remains secret until the called card is played. A standard 52 card pack is used.

Deal
Any player may deal first, and the turn to deal passes to the left after each hand. The cards are not shuffled between deals: the dealer simply gathers the cards from the previous hand, stacking the tricks together, cuts the pack and starts dealing. The deal will result in everyone having a hand of 13 cards.

Bidding
Bids are an undertaking to win at least the stated number of tricks with the help of a partner chosen by nominating a card. The bidder will choose the trump suit but the bids do not mention a suit, only the number of tricks.

Play
The highest bidder leads to the first trick, naming the trump suit and the called card. The identity of the partner is definitively revealed only when the called card is played, though it may be guessed earlier because the partner will try to play cards that will help the bidder.

Scoring
The bid succeeds if the bidder together with the holder of the nominated card win at least as many tricks as the number that was bid. In this case they each score the amount of the bid. If the bidder and partner fail to win enough tricks between them, the other two players score the amount of the bid.

A separate cumulative score is kept for each player and the game can continue until someone reaches the agreed target score, typically 101. The player with most points then wins.

name: Braintown
description:
Cerebronians are here! And they are invading Earth! Well... They are invading Braintown... but eventually...

Braintown is a game for 2 to 5 players who play as cerebronians: mind controlling alliens. The cerebronians want to start their invasion and they need to choose a good leader. The best cerebronians are selected to compete in a real invasion scenario: Braintown, a little town populated by normal and weird citizens.

Each player uses his or her dice to control cards by getting high values and by throwing them in the correct place over the field.

Each player will have an objective. Each objective consists in eliminating some inhabitants. The first player to achieve his or her objective, wins the game and becomes the leading cerebronian!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Memory, Push Your Luck

name: Desperados of Dice Town: Mister Phal Promo Character
description:
Promo Character card gift during Cannes Fair 2014.

Promo character 'Mister Phal' to be played by replacing one from the 4 gangs.

It replaces the 'wicked' character from one gang (the easiest to free). Its power is to make freed characters to be able to play according to your dice roll.

name: "Bob"ball!
description:
(#@*^, it's fun!)

The official game of OverMen everywhere; "Bob"ball! offers the perfect combination of awesome and balls in a revolutionary, mind-altering format. This instant classic is a re-imagining of the longer-to-brew hit game you've heard only whispers about from another tier of consciousness.

"Bob"ball! is a game for two players. Try to save your mutant family and get them to the Pleasure Saucers before X-Day. Beware, there's only enough room for one more family. The other will be condemned to fry on Earth with the rest of the Normals.

So pull the wool over your own eyes, grab some dice, and praise "Bob" or kill him. You've never seen balls like these.

Use your "Bob"balls to bounce around along the grid to pick up family members and deliver them to the Pleasure Saucers. Each turn, roll three dice, assign the values to each "Bob"ball, and move. Make them hit your opponent's ball and transfer movement power to form chain reactions to keep them from scoring. Hitting another "Bob"ball stops yours and can transfer a family from one to another.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Matching Manatees
description:
A memory card game of trying to get your manatees home avoiding getting hit by the boats.
"The cards are set up in a 5x5 grid. This is the "ocean" where the manatees are swimming. The 4 corners is where the "home" cards go and the very center is a stack of shuffled boat cards that should be face up. All other spaces should each have stacks of two manatee cards on them face down. "
"On your turn, you...

----1. Flip over two manatee cards. If they match, leave them face up. If they do not match, turn them face down again. (OR: if there is a stack of two face-down manatee cards adjacent to an empty space with no manatee cards, you may move the top card from the stack of two into the empty space instead of flipping any cards over.)

----2. If any of YOUR manatees are face up, you may move one of them toward their home location. If you have face up manatee cards that are adjacent to each other, any adjacent manatee can follow the card that moved by moving into the space it just left, and an adjacent manatee can follow that card, and so on. Manatees move up/down and left/right but not diagonal. If a manatee makes it home, that manatee is safe and counts as a point toward winning.

----3. If you moved a manatee you have to move a boat one space too (unless there are no boats left). The boat has to go toward the location matching the manatee on the card, moving up/down and left/right but not diagonal. If the boat lands on the same space as any face-up manatee, the manatee is removed from the game. The boat only moves one space per turn, even if several manatees moved by following the manatee you initially moved. When the boat makes it to the home location, the boat is out of the game.

(Note: You can play competitively or cooperatively. You can move the boats to take your opponents manatees out of the game on purpose or you can work together to have none of the manatees get hit by boats.
Players keep taking turns until one of the players has all of their manatees out of the game, either from getting hit by a boat or making it safely home. At this point, players should count up all the manatees they got home. Each manatee counts as one point. Whoever has the most points wins."

name: Jazz
description:
Jazz (sometimes spelled Jass) is a game played with a traditional deck of cards, not to be confused with the Swiss game by the same name played with a special 36-card jass deck. The ideal number of players is four, but it can be adapted for three or five by removing one or two of the number 2 cards for a total of 51=3*17 or 50=5*10 cards.

The game is a fixed collection of several short games and the winner is the player with the lowest total score. There are slight variants of the exact composition of included games and the scoring, however all but one are always trick-taking games while the last one is a variant of the game Fan Tan. All games start by dealing the entire deck so that each player receives the same number of cards. Common for all the trick-taking games is the requirement to follow suit if possible. The player of the highest card (ace being the highest) in that suit takes the trick and starts the next one. If a player lacks cards in the suit on the table he plays any one card of his own choice.

Most Jazz variants consist of a selection of four to six of the following trick-taking games plus the final game of Fan Tan. The provided suggested penalty points provide for a balanced four-person game.

1. "Spades" or "Clubs"
A trick-taking game where the aim is to avoid taking cards of the specified suit. (2p each)

2a. "Tricks", "Zero", or "Minus"
Take as few tricks as possible. (2p each)
2b. "Plus"
Take as many tricks as possible. (-2p each) This seems to be a rare variant to include.

3. "Honors"
Avoid taking honor cards, i.e. 10, J, Q, and K. (2p each)

4a. "Jacks"
4b. "Queens"
Depending on the variant, one should avoid taking either jacks or queens. (5p each) Some variants play both the Jacks and the Queens games one after the other, others play only one of them.

5. "King of Hearts and the Final Trick"
Avoid taking the very last trick as well as the king of hearts card. Some variants also give penalty points for the fifth trick. (10p each, sometimes with an extra penalty for taking the king of hearts as part of the final trick.)

6. "Solitaire", "Seven", "Fan Tan"
The final game is Fan Tan or a version thereof. One common rule specifies that the player having the 7 of diamonds always goes first by playing this card while another variant is started by normal clock-wise order and with any number seven card. The starting player is often allowed/required to play an additional card if possible. In each suit the 7 is played first followed by the 8 on one side and as the third card the 6 on the other side of the 7. As soon as these three cards have been played the ascending (9-K) and descending (5-A) runs of the suit are played independently of one another on top of the 8 and 6 cards. A player has to play one and only one card on his turn if possible. The game ends when a player runs out of cards. The other players score 3p for each remaining card of their own.

name: Who Wants To Be a Millionaire: Hot Seat â The Board Game
description:
FROM THE BOX:

Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? Hot Seat is a fast-paced, tension-filled TV game show - a contest of chance, strategy and wits. Now you can enjoy all the excitement of the show with this fun family board game edition.

There's 2 ways to play and hundreds of fun and interesting questions that will delight and challenge your family and friends many times over.

So get everyone together and see who can survive the Hot Seat!

name: What the Food?! âO Canada!â
description: What the Food?! add-on “O Canada” bonus cards (the unique combo of Maple syrup and Poutine) are fun Kickstarter extras that came up during our campaign. Someone asked in the comments if we had maple syrup, and I was shocked that we didn’t - yet. So we added this food and topping in honor of our Canadian artist and team members on the project.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Humor
mechanics: Action Queue, Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: ÐÐ¾Ñ ÐÐµÑÐµÐ»Ð° Ð¤ÐµÑÐ¼Ð°
description:
My Happy Farm is a game in which players strive to become the best farmer.

All players have their own farm with four nice animals. They feed those cuties. Animals which are fed well fill their stomachs with tasty food, grow and become longer and longer, even reaching unnatural lengths. The longer your animal, the better a farmer you are. The owner of the longest animal receives bonus points. Animals which aren't fed even one time lose their weight, take offense, and leave their bad master. Moreover, they will take some victory points from the bad master to punish him, so players have to be good and careful farmers and feed their animals well to create Their Own Happy Farm.

This is a new edition with new art and the box is already contains the expansion Gazda.

name: ZERO Hour: Cyberspace
description:
The Dice Manipulation and Strategy Game about Cyber Threats in the 21st Century.

ZERO Hour: Cyberspace is a game about creating and managing Cyber Threats in the 21st Century.

This is accomplished by using the innovative ZERO HOUR GAME SYSTEM.
The ZERO HOUR GAME SYSTEM uses twenty-four sided (D24) dice that you as the player will manipulate and move as playing pieces through the course of the game.

This is the first in a series of unique games that will utilize the
ZERO HOUR GAME SYSTEM in order to create a myriad of game experiences with one basic rules structure that you as players can expand to your liking.

The objective of each Player is to maneuver their Code Dice thru The Network (game board), and place two of their five Code Dice into any opposing active Player(s) Source space on the game board.

The game ends once one player achieves the objective of having two Code Dice in any opposing active Player(s) Source space. That player is immediately declared the Winner.

Alternatively, if all Players have a Terminated Hard Line, the game ends immediately. The Winner of the game is the player with the highest value showing on a Code Die in an opposing Player’s Source space.

The Winner of the Game is the player with the highest value showing on a Code Die in an opposing Player’s Source space.

name: Rivalry of Local Barons
description:
Issue game of Wargame Japanese History #22.

Strategic level wargame of the Japanese Sengoku period.
The basic game concept is inspired from History of the World, and has a shorter playtime and is simpler.

Each turn, players select one of the six revealed warlord cards. The top order card can be taken free, but the second or later card requires a "Heaven's will" chit. These chits can be taken by the later chooser of the skipped cards.
Each warlord card has a strength and special abilities, and also attached a support card.
The battle is resolved by a die with a very simple combat result table.

The winner is determined by victory points, earned for the control of provinces and other bonuses.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Simulation, Variable Player Powers

name: X-Hour: XenoStrike
description:
X-Hour: XenoStrike is an action point-based dice allocation game in which you command an elite combat team in Advanced Personnel Exo-Suits, affectionately known as APEs. Your mission is to exterminate Xenomorphs that have infested a facility before it gets overwhelmed by their incessant spawning.

The Xenomorphs have anticipated your team's insertion and have positioned Xeno Sentinels to guard their spawn sites, while a Xeno Prowler roams the facility, hunting your APEs.

name: Super Turbo bitCrawl FX: Alpha Xtreme
description:
Super Turbo bitCrawl FX: Alpha Xtreme is a co-op game designed for 1-8 players in which our heroes venture through a dungeon in search of treasure, adventure and eventually the BOSS FIGHT!!

At the beginning of the game, players are given a choice of eight classes within the standard four fantasy archetypes: Mage, Priest, Rogue, and Warrior. Each class has a specific number of starting dice for basic attack and agility rolls and class specific skill that is unique for each of the eight classes. After players have chosen their class they are tasked with selecting the skills that their character will possess for the duration of the game. There are eight double-sided ability inserts available to each archetype allowing for a total of 24 unique versions of each of the available eight classes. Players then select their portrait and sprite representation for this game.

Once players have selected their class, abilities, and portrait, the players select the boss they will face at the end of the game. There are two bosses in the base game, along with eight abilities for the bosses to possess. This allows for a total of 48 unique bosses that the players can encounter at the end of the game.

Once set-up has completed, our heroes embark on their adventure through the dungeon.

A turn is divided into two phases. The first phase is the exploration phase during this phase each hero has 3 exploration actions that they can take. These include things such as moving into a new tile, scrounging rooms for treasure, equipping items and resting to name a few. After each hero has taken their three exploration actions it is now time for the encounter phase. Random targeting determines where the encounter(s) will be taking place, the hero(es) that have been assigned an encounter will roll the encounter die to determine what they will have to contend with, be it monsters, events or nothing at all. During the encounter phase each hero is allowed one action and the encounter phase does not end until all monsters have been defeated. After the monsters have been dealt with the heroes gain experience and divvy up the treasure. The "Player One" marker is moved all heroes move their special ability dice closer to the ready and the new player one starts the turn with their three exploration actions.

The dungeon and all things in it, including the boss, are designed to scale based on the number of heroes playing and the highest level hero in the dungeon. As heroes level up they gain additional attack or agility dice and their special abilities require less of a cool down between uses.

The base game includes 26 hex tiles, which the heroes reveal as they explore the dungeon. The boss fight is triggered by the random pull of one of these tiles that is labeled "BOSS FIGHT!!!" when this tile is entered all heroes teleport to the tile to do battle with the boss. STbCFX:AX is a co-op game at its core but does allow for a competitive element tied to the value of the treasure that the heroes collect while exploring the dungeon.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Role Playing, Variable Player Powers

name: Titanium Wars: Kraken
description: Kraken is an additional destroyer-class ship for Titanium Wars. It requires Tech 3 and 2000¢ to build, and delivers 10 Attack, while being protected by 25 Defense. It sports 5 upgrade slots.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Negotiation, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: Intrigo: Muiters van de Zeven ZeeÃ«n
description:
In Intrigo the players are pirates on a pirate ship. Half of the ship's crew is loyal to the captain, but the other half is plotting to kill the captain and take control of the ship. Who will come out of this struggle victoriously?

At the start of the game each player will receive a card. On this card is a unique role and a team indication (either red or blue). Many of the roles have some sort of special power. Players do not show their role card to others. Only one player will reveal his role immediately: this is the player which has the captain role (and who is on the blue team).
The blue team wins if they succeed in killing all of the players in the red team. The red team wins if they succeed in killing the captain. However, as long as the blue player with the bodyguard role is alive, the captain cannot be killed by red players.

The game plays in night and day phases, just like in Werewolf. In the first night, the captain and bodyguard will get to know each other. Also, the players on the red team will get to know each other, but only partially: one player on the red team is the team leader. This player will open his eyes ("wake up") and will make eye contact with other red players one-by-one. This means that the red team leader knows who all of the red players are, but all the other red players will only know the red team leader but none of the other team mates.

In the game, players are eliminated at night by roles that become active then (usually red players). Players are also eliminated by day, as at the end of each day usually one player will be nominated to "walk the plank" (and will thus be eliminated). The captain can never be nominated to walk the plank. There are various player roles which can perform special night and day actions. These actions include finding out more about other players, kill them, or protect them.

What sets this game apart from Werewolf is that most of the night actions require the player performing them to actually touch the player to which it is directed. This not only makes it harder to kill players further away from you, it also increases chances that some kind of noise or movement will be felt by the other players (which have their eyes closed during the nights). This in turn gives players during the day 'evidence' to accuse other players of being on the red team, and thus a good candidate to 'walk the plank'!

Intrigo shares game mechanisms with Werewolf (e.g., two teams that battle for victory, day/night phases, hidden roles with special powers) and BANG! (hidden roles and only one role is known to all players).

The game is language-dependent: the texts on the cards are in the Dutch language, and currently there is only a Dutch rule set available.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Negotiation, Party Game, Pirates

name: Star Trek: Attack Wing â Tholia One Expansion Pack (Retail)
description:
Tholian starships were small starships of characteristic shape, utilized by the Tholian Assembly during the 23rd century. These vessels were armed with plasma torpedo-like torpedo weaponry. But their most powerful weapon was the so-called "Tholian web". This web was "weaved" by two or more Tholian vessels around an enemy ship. This web could be used as a high power immobilization field/tractor beam to pull captured starships back to Tholian territory.

This expansion comes with one new ship and a new set of cards for Star Trek: Attack Wing.

Star Trek: Attack Wing – Tholia One Expansion Pack (Retail) is part of the Wave 12 expansion packs from WizKids Games.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Super Tooth: Sunny Days Expansion
description: This expansion to Super Tooth consists of nine cards: 1 Hot Sun Event Card, 2 awesome Meat-Eating Spinosaurus Cards, and 6 Plant-Eating Corythosaurus Cards. The explanation and rules for each card in this expansion can be found on the Expansion Events reference card.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Expansion for Base-game, Prehistoric

name: Super Tooth: Time Travelers Expansion
description: This expansion to Super Tooth is comprised of 7 cards: 1 Time Portal Event card and 6 unique Time Traveler cards. The Time Travelers can be very helpful to players during the game, but are susceptible to Landscape-clearing Events and will get sucked back in time by the Time Portal Event. The explanation of the Time Portal Event and each of the Time Traveler abilities may be found on the 3 Time Traveler reference cards.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Expansion for Base-game, Prehistoric

name: Super Tooth: Roaming Daspletosaurus Expansion
description: This expansion to Super Tooth is comprised of a plastic card stand and three cards: 1 Roaming Daspletosaurus Event card and 2 cutout figure cards for you to create your own stand-up cutout of this fearsome predator. The explanation and rules for this expansion may be found on the Roaming Daspletosaurus reference card.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Expansion for Base-game, Prehistoric

name: The Amega Weapon
description:
The Amega Weapon is all about defeating your opponents in a deep space war while surviving the dreaded Black Star, which is a totally random object that wreaks destruction wherever it goes.

While conventional weapons cause damage, The Amega Weapon quickly destroys ships, therefore, players want to obtain the parts to the weapon, build the weapon, then use the weapon to obliterate their opponents. The last star warrior standing rules the Parax System.

The Amega Weapon is played on a game board that is created by placing 4 different boards together in any way, shape, or fashion that you choose with over 30,000 possible game board variations. The boards are the beautiful artwork of Greg Winters, illustrator of Star Wars featuring 12 planets, 6 star bases, novae, and asteroids. Greg also created our fantastic box cover.

The Amega Weapon showcases 7 custom designed pewter playing pieces that we spin cast ourselves. Additional components include: top notch quality Mission Profile cards, Deep Space cards, Asteroid cards, and 6 denominations of money along with two 6-sided dice, a 10-sided die, and a 20-sided die.

Players can elect to play one-on-one, team play, or a regular game. The game is player tested for ages 12 and up with a special kid's game for ages 6 and up that does not interfere with the normal game.
The questions you have to ask yourself are: Can you obtain The Amega Weapon? Can you obliterate your opponents? Will you survive the Black Star? Do you even think you stand a chance? Got control??? Think again, lol!!!
categories: Fighting, Humor, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Pick-up and Deliver, Player Elimination, Point to Point Movement, Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Global Mogul: Entrepreneur
description: This expansion adds 10 tiles with special abilities that players receive at the beginning of the game. Each player received 1 tile and it is either random or picked in reverse turn order.

name: Scotland Rising: Falkirk
description:
The year 1298; almost a year after the Battle of Stirling Bridge, the Scots and the English meet again: William Wallace now face King Edward "Longshanks" I.

In this extra map for Scotland Rising, you and a friend take control of either the Scots Brave or the English Army on the famoues Battle of Falkirk!
Lead your men as King Edward I and secure the English victory - or change history and give Scotland it's freedom by leading Wallace and his men.

This map was originally a Kickstarter streach goal, but unfortunately it was not met, so the publisher decided to publish it digitally on Scotland Rising's webpage.
To play this map you will need the counters (or blocks add-ons for a fog-of-war) from the base game.
The map uses base game rules.

Map size 11 x 17 inces.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: 9 Rings 4 a Row
description:
Boardless 4-in-a-row type game where the players' moves are dictated by the position of nine rings on the table.

9 Rings 4 a Row is played with 9 rings and 40 pawns in two colors. The pawns fit inside the rings.

Players alternate placing a pawn in a ring and then moving this ring orthogonaly adjacent to another ring. The first player to align 4 pawns in their color in any direction wins the game.

This game is based on a Hungarian TV-show, where famous actors improvise in strange situations, for example they can only ask questions, or each of them gets a number and is allowed to say sentences containing exactly that many words. In this game the players do the same.

This is the first expansion of the original game.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: VETO Konfrontacja
description:
Non-CCG card game for two people.

Explore the world in which swords chop to the left and right, while men screaming off their lungs. World of mighty Karmazyns and Brotherhood. World of XVII-century Poland. World of Noble Card Game VETO!

Starting the game in Veto The confrontation, you can choose whether you stand on the side of a knightly family of Michael Volodyovski headed, or insidious Radziwill, where the first saber is Andrew Kmicic. Your actions can support Jeremy WiÅniowiecki or treacherous brothers Radziwill in the struggle for the throne of Poland. By hook or by crook you will agitate and challenge to duels their rivals.

Do not have pity for the vanquished! Grab throne for yourself!

This is a standalone game, based on CCG Szlachecka Gra Karciana VETO! (Noble Card Game VETO!) and contains two complete decks of 55 cards, 28 ducat tokens, 15 stroke tokens and instruction.

name: Minimize
description:
Minimize is a game that seems to yield some fierce tactics despite being extremely simple. You could even play with Xs and Os.

You almost always want to play your opponent's color, trying to build small "territories" that you can create tiny groups in. Beginners should definitely start out on the base 5 grid and slowly work their way up to larger boards.

The rules are explained here: http://www.scribd.com/doc/260002289/Minimize

It should be mentioned that it seems to work on square grids as well, and some people even prefer it that way.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Print & Play, Territory Building

name: Caccia a Tito: Drvar 1944
description:
English description:

"Caccia a Tito Drvar 1944" is a tactical wargame (TA1) using the same rules of "La Battaglia di Gravellona Toce 1944" which simulates the Operation Roesselsprung (Knight's Move), codename for the avio operation acted by 500th SS Para Battalion to chase Marshal Tito in May 1944. Each point is 40 men and each turn is about 2 hours each.

Italian description:

"Caccia a Tito Drvar 1944" è un wargame tattico (TA1) che intende simulare l’operazione Rösselsprung ("Salto del Cavaliere" in tedesco), nome in codice dell’attacco aviotrasportato del 500° Battaglione Paracadutisti SS su Drvar, città sede del Comando del Maresciallo Tito, comandante dei partigiani comunisti jugoslavi il 25 Maggio 1944.
La scala di gioco è di circa 40 uomini per punto di Valore di Forza e il turno è di 2 ore circa.
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight

name: Reclaim Oz
description:
Reclaim Oz is a nontraditional deck building strategy game that takes places in a Dystopian Oz overruled by Four Witches. Reclaim Oz is unlike other deckbuilding games because of the combination of PvP elements and a limitation to the size of each players deck. It is a unique tabletop experience that has the play differently than any other games in the same genre.
If you didn’t know already, the game takes place in the Wonderful Land of Oz, but at a time when it wasn’t so wonderful. All the great Legends of Oz have disappeared, and four Witches from the Silver Islands. While L. Frank Baum may have written a much happier world, this is still the same place, with all the characters and places you know in love—but in a time of great terror. The game consists of animals, beasts, and mythos—it is your task to get the World back to the way it once was, with the characters you know and love. If you are able to compile the best deck filling each of the four categories (HEART, COURAGE, BRAIN, HOME), you win!

The one thing that makes this card game different than a traditional deck building game is the lack of currency and ability to purchase cards. The cards are given to you each turn, Cards are marked with symbols letting you know how they are used in the game, the symbols include: Heart, Courage, Brain, Home, and Wicked. All of these cards are used in different ways. *All Card Designs Are Subject to Change". Throughout the Game you must build your Deck via placing it on the Game Board, once an item is placed--it’s there until the game ends.

The game ends when all four witches have been played, Witches can not be discarded but played into their discard pile that will affect one or all players in the game. To play a Witch Card place the character face up on the table and explain the action that must take place, some witches have you attack single players while others affect everyone in the game. The Witch Cards play a pivotal role in the gameplay and can only be diverted if a Defense Card in Hand is playable and not vaulted. All Witch Cards caused whichever players/cards affected to be Trashed and will no longer be used in gameplay.

Once the game ends and the cards on the Game Board are tallied, the winner has the most Road Points in their Vaulted Deck is the winner. In the result of a tie the player with the highest Road Point Legend is the Winner.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Adventure, Children's Game, Fantasy, Novel-based
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Player Elimination, Set Collection, Take That, Variable Player Powers
